results.title: ‘The Godfather of A.I.’ Leaves Google and Warns of Danger Ahead
results.abstract: For half a century, Geoffrey Hinton nurtured the technology at the heart of chatbots like ChatGPT. Now he worries it will cause serious harm.

media.caption: Dr. Geoffrey Hinton is leaving Google so that he can freely share his concern that artificial intelligence could cause the world serious harm.

results.title: Gordon Lightfoot, Hitmaking Singer-Songwriter, Is Dead at 84
results.abstract: His rich baritone voice and songs like “Sundown,” “The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald” and “If You Could Read My Mind” made him a top artist of the 1970s.

media.caption: Gordon Lightfoot in performance in London in 1973. When he moved beyond folk music and began writing ballads aimed at a broader audience in the 1970s, he scored one hit after another.

results.title: Man Dies on Subway After Another Rider Placed Him in a Chokehold
results.abstract: The police said the man, 30, was acting erratically on an F train Monday afternoon when another man, 24, placed him in a chokehold.

results.title: How ‘The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald’ Defied Top 40 Logic
results.abstract: Gordon Lightfoot’s 1976 folk ballad told the true story of a shipwreck on Lake Superior. One of his old friends called it “a documentarian’s song.”

media.caption: The Edmund Fitzgerald slides into its launching basin in Detroit on June 7, 1958. The ship would sink in Lake Superior 17 years later.

results.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and Jean Chung
results.title: A Brutal Sex Trade Built for American Soldiers
results.abstract: It’s a long-buried part of South Korean history: women compelled by force, trickery or desperation into prostitution, with the complicity of their own leaders.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

media.caption: In Dongducheon, South Korea, north of Seoul, women forced to work as prostitutes to American soldiers in the decades after the Korean War were confined in this building when they were discovered to have a sexually transmitted disease.

results.adx_keywords: Jews and Judaism;Housing and Real Estate;New York City
results.title: In Mezuzas, a Custom Inherited by Gentiles
results.abstract: Jews have left their mark on every aspect of New York life, but perhaps none so ubiquitous as the palm-length encasements attached to countless doorways.

media.caption: Connie Peirce, a Catholic, was delighted when a Jewish neighbor affixed a mezuza on the doorway of her home in Peter Cooper Village in Manhattan.

results.title: A Giant Blob of Seaweed Is Heading to Florida
results.abstract: The mass, known as the great Atlantic Sargassum belt, is drifting toward the Gulf of Mexico. Scientists say seaweed is likely to come ashore by summer to create a rotting, stinking, scourge.

media.caption: A worker removing sargassum with machinery at a resort in Cancun, Mexico, last year.

results.abstract: A reader is offended by the gardener next door, whose impulse to use her green thumb has led her to trim other people’s hedges without asking.
